questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with a history of seizures that occurred twice within the last 24 hours. Each episode lasted about 20 minutes and involved jerking movements of one side of the body. The child had a fever of 39°C (102.2°F) at the time of the seizures. What is the most accurate definition of complex febrile seizures?

options.label: A
options.text: Generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting ≤15 minutes and not recurrent within 24 hours.

options.label: C
options.text: Focal seizure, which is prolonged for >15 minutes and/or recurs in 24 hours.

questions.correct_answer: C. Focal seizure, which is prolonged for >15 minutes and/or recurs in 24 hours.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complex febrile seizures are characterized by focal seizures that last more than 15 minutes and/or recur within 24 hours. Distinguishing between simple and complex febrile seizures is crucial for appropriate management and follow-up.
  • ➤ Complex febrile seizures are characterized by focal seizures that last more than 15 minutes and/or recur within 24 hours.
  • ➤ Distinguishing between simple and complex febrile seizures is crucial for appropriate management and follow-up.

questions.text: A patient with 50% body burns is admitted and subsequently develops an infection at the site of the burns. A swab from the infection site was cultured, and the isolate showed strict aerobic characteristics along with the positive oxidase test as shown in the image. Which organism is most likely responsible for this burn infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of infection in burn patients due to its robust survival mechanisms and characteristic oxidase-positive reaction. Prompt identification and appropriate treatment are critical to manage its potential severe complications effectively. Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.
  • ➤ Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of infection in burn patients due to its robust survival mechanisms and characteristic oxidase-positive reaction.
  • ➤ Prompt identification and appropriate treatment are critical to manage its potential severe complications effectively.
  • ➤ Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase.
  • ➤ Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen.
  • ➤ Enterobacteriaceae (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

The therapist explains a technique involving him and his partner stopping sexual stimulation before the point of imminent ejaculation, waiting for a few seconds, and then starting again to build control over ejaculation timing. This technique is known as:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Seman’s Technique

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Seman's squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological method used to delay ejaculation in men with premature ejaculation. Here, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation, the sex is stopped for some time and once the excitement has decreased, it is restarted. Hence, it is also known as the stop-start technique .
  • ➤ Seman's squeeze technique is a non-pharmacological method used to delay ejaculation in men with premature ejaculation.
  • ➤ Here, when the man gets the feeling of impending ejaculation, the sex is stopped for some time and once the excitement has decreased, it is restarted.
  • ➤ Hence, it is also known as the stop-start technique .
  • ➤ stop-start technique

Ans.

Explanation:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient? 1. Atorvastatin 2. Aspirin 3. Clopidogrel 4. Low molecular weight heparin 5. Alteplase
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:
  • • 1. Atorvastatin : High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.
  • • 1. Atorvastatin
  • • 2. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.
  • • 2. Aspirin:
  • • 3. Clopidogrel : Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.
  • • 3. Clopidogrel
  • • 4. Low molecular weight heparin : Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.
  • • 4. Low molecular weight heparin
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • 5. Alteplase : This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.
  • • 5. Alteplase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones binds to nuclear receptors?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Thyroid hormones

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Thyroid hormones bind to nuclear receptors, which are located within the cell nucleus. Upon binding to their receptors, thyroid hormones modulate gene expression by acting as transcription factors. This mechanism contrasts with hormones like glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids that bind to cytoplasmic receptors, and hormones like ACTH and catecholamines that bind to cell surface G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Glucocorticoids: Bind to cytoplasmic receptors.
  • • Option A. Glucocorticoids:
  • • Option C. ACTH: Binds to G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) on the cell surface.
  • • Option C. ACTH:
  • • Option D. Catecholamines - β receptors: Bind to cell surface receptors that activate the Gs protein-coupled receptor pathway.
  • • Option D. Catecholamines - β receptors:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroid hormones bind to nuclear receptors, influencing gene expression and regulating various metabolic processes. Understanding the receptor binding mechanisms of different hormones is crucial for comprehending their physiological actions and therapeutic targets.
